distributional 0.3.1.9000

The Pareto distribution

Source: R/dist_pareto.R
dist_pareto.Rd

dist_pareto(shape, scale)

Arguments

shape, scale

parameters. Must be strictly positive.

See also

actuar::Pareto

Examples

dist <- dist_pareto(shape = c(10, 3, 2, 1), scale = rep(1, 4))
dist
#> <distribution[4]>
#> [1] Pareto(10, 1) Pareto(3, 1)  Pareto(2, 1)  Pareto(1, 1) 

mean(dist)
#> [1] 0.1111111 0.5000000 1.0000000       Inf
variance(dist)
#> [1] 0.0154321 0.7500000       Inf       NaN
support(dist)
#> <support_region[4]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1] 0.10415484 0.02165317 0.01150541 0.28313117 0.05618554 0.02278973
#>  [7] 0.11159186 0.10914234 0.01906435 0.20123734
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 1.04610237 0.12614579 0.16608005 0.49448518 0.43068752 0.28340225
#>  [7] 0.40013732 0.34824358 0.09806869 0.02084870
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 2.2615639 0.6499975 0.6987805 1.9141982 0.9382139 0.4146082 0.1543576
#>  [8] 0.1860912 0.4722029 0.6590440
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.23085838 2.18879757 3.35890579 3.93959495 2.54313839 0.05087076
#>  [7] 0.24554990 0.43135155 4.20395680 2.67921790
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 5.645029e-05 3.703704e-02 7.407407e-02 1.111111e-01
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -9.782150 -3.295837 -2.602690 -2.197225

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.9999999 0.9920000 0.9600000 0.8000000

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 0.1279449 0.4938016 0.8257419 2.3333333
